citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection there were two kittens that were showing signs of illness whereby the licensee did not address
appropriately. One of them, a Bengal female (microchip #: 985141005790573) that was identified on the last report (June
9, 2023) with crusts and clear nasal discharge located in the white cage near the kitchen, received veterinary care (exam
and treatment initiation) on the same day. However, per the licensee, this kitten has been getting worse and the
veterinarian was not notified until the inspector observed and mentioned concerning clinical signs – including lethargy
(new clinical sign), thick, yellowish-brown nasal crusts, as well as yellowish-brown nasal discharge in right nostril. On the
evening of Friday, June 9, 2023, the licensee identified a separate Leopard cat kitten (no microchip), that was not taken in
for treatment that day with the others, as appearing ill with watery eyes. The licensee elected to initiate medical treatment
on this animal, using the same medication as the other kittens, without consulting a veterinarian. The licensee notified the
veterinarian about the condition of this animal during the same call regarding the Bengal kitten. Failure to use appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries can foster an unhealthy environment, delay the
onset of diagnosing and treating ailments, and can consequently lead to unnecessary suffering and death. Each dealer
shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Both cats that were identified by the inspector need to be examined
and treated by a veterinarian.
On the same date, a focused inspection was conducted, whereby the findings from the inspection will be forthcoming in
an additional report. These findings did not rise to the level of direct or critical non-compliances.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
BRENTON COX, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR
Madeline Anna, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection there were two kittens that were showing signs of illness whereby the licensee did not address 
appropriately. One of them, a Bengal female (microchip #: 985141005790573) that was identified on the last report (June 
9, 2023) with crusts and clear nasal discharge located in the white cage near the kitchen, received veterinary care (exam 
and treatment initiation) on the same day. However, per the licensee, this kitten has been getting worse and the 
veterinarian was not notified until the inspector observed and mentioned concerning clinical signs – including lethargy 
(new clinical sign), thick, yellowish-brown nasal crusts, as well as yellowish-brown nasal discharge in right nostril. On the 
evening of Friday, June 9, 2023, the licensee identified a separate Leopard cat kitten (no microchip), that was not taken in 
for treatment that day with the others, as appearing ill with watery eyes. The licensee elected to initiate medical treatment 
on this animal, using the same medication as the other kittens, without consulting a veterinarian. The licensee notified the 
veterinarian about the condition of this animal during the same call regarding the Bengal kitten. Failure to use appropriate 
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries can foster an unhealthy environment, delay the 
onset of diagnosing and treating ailments, and can consequently lead to unnecessary suffering and death. Each dealer 
shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. Both cats that were identified by the inspector need to be examined 
and treated by a veterinarian.  
 
On the same date, a focused inspection was conducted, whereby the findings from the inspection will be forthcoming in 
an additional report. These findings did not rise to the level of direct or critical non-compliances. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
BRENTON COX, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR 
Madeline Anna, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
